div.p: end to their suffering[.] It is no less than surprising that about 600 horse-men would be out upwards of two months & would not be ashamed to come back in such a t[…] triumph with only 3 Scalps: The fact was that they revenged themselves on the first they met with & I believe that it is a common maxim with every Indian nation to turn back when they shed blood or after the first attack thinking that they gain laurels enough if they attack at all; tho' their passion for revenge is not quenched[.] Thoese warriors entered the Village triumphantly with the Scalps held up on long poles, & those who were lingering in sickness got their feet & joined the process[.] Without enquiring after their relations, which the hand of death had prevented from a reciprocal rejoicing; the procession continued to the other Villages; & the bewailling for their Children, their nearest relations, as well as the death of those young men who were killed at war turned to rejoicing oif singing dancing & riotting can be so called[.] Notwithstanding, a Mother could be heard to burst out a crying in the heat of joy for the loss of images more dear to her than the Scalp of an enemy[.]

If I may hasard an opinion of my own, I believe that whosoever will look into the Indian passions that they will find them to be transitory, & all their life, a life of extremes[.] no No being can bear with more manly fortitude a wound if attained at war, than they do; but should they cut their feet with an Ax, or fell ill with natural sickness they are on the other extreme[.] They are indolent, capricious, contemptuous & revengeful to the last degree; & yet their passions do not seem to disturb the quiet of their mind, which almost always appears regular & Calm[.] Indians in general bear Femine with great fortitude, & when they have it in abundance they devour their vital[s]
